content.description: The start is to the right of the Carry A Big Stick flake and just left of the flake at the bottom of the unnamed gully used for setting the toprope.  The route heads directly up the face of the slab.  Friction steps and smearing are the order of the day.  Variation:  Deviate to the left of the fall line near the top to climb on small nubbins.  The rock has a lighter coloration in this area and the climbing is about a grade easier.
content.location: A toprope can be setup using the gully just right of this route.

content.description: An easy route for children.  This gully is the easiest way to setup a toprope for the other routes.  An adult on this route can also point out foot placements on Walk Softly.  If soloing, be careful down climbing the route as some of the foot placements can be a bit grainy below the cracks near the top.
content.protection: Toprope or solo to setup a toprope for the other routes

content.description: The obvious crack visible from the loop trail. Hand to fist size, and even wider in some spots. Straight up then finish on the flake as the crack turns slightly left near the top. Slightly overhanging for the first half. Rock surface is rough and will chew up your hands, but fun route nonetheless.
content.protection: About a size 3 or so C4 and around that size up the crack. Two bolts on top. Can be lead or set up as top rope, though scramble to top can be a bit sketchy. You could also just do it as a boulder problem, just a little on the higher side
content.location: First route you encounter just after you turn right onto the loop trail. It will be on your left side. Also the northeasternmost significant rock in the area. Further north from Walk Softly, on the other side of the Huge Boulder

content.description: Proceed up the right side of the large flake to the top.  This is an excellent route for kids and beginning climbers.  The start can be difficult for children.

There are more than a dozen routes and problems in this area covering a wide range of difficulty.  Most of the routes can be top-roped using bolts that are generally in good condition.  According to Prescott Bouldering, this area is also called The Shipyard.
